 THE TRANSPORT SECTOR A. Economic Growth and Impact 1.1 Lao PDR is poor, landlocked, mountainous and sparsely populated (4.9 million in 1995). The level of economic and social development is among the lowest in the world, with a per capita income of US$350 per year (1995), a life expectancy of about 52 years and an incidence of poverty at 46%. Much of the country's basic infrastructure has been destroyed through wars and lack of regular maintenance, which has resulted in poor physical integration of the country's 16 provinces (plus the Vientiane Municipality and the Special Zone of Xaysomboune). Over half of the Lao population lives in small, scattered villages without regular access to transport means. Agricultural activities generate 54% of GDP and employ 80% of the labor force. 1.2 In 1986 the Government launched the New Economic Mechanism (NEM) to move the economy from a system of centralized planning to one with a market orientation. Since then, external trade and most prices have been liberalized, subsidies to state enterprises have been largely eliminated, and the exchange rate has been aligned with the market rate. The Government's commitment to reform has been generally positive. Strengthened public and private investment and economic incentives contributed to a rise in per capita income of nearly 5% per annum in real terms. Inflation fell from nearly 60% in 1989 to single digits in the early 1990s (6.8% in 1994) and the overall fiscal deficit was reduced from 13.4% to 9.2% of GDP between 1990 and 1995. Growth prospects are good for the remainder of the decade, with GDP expected to grow by about 7% per year.1 B. The Transport System 1.3 Lao PDR's transport system - roads, inland waterways and air transport - is rudimentary, dilapidated and unreliable. Factors contributing to the decline are the legacy of years of hostilities which destroyed a substantial part of the transport infrastructure; weak institutions and human resources responsible for transport infrastructure; and inadequate funds committed to the preservation of the country's transport assets. Moreover, the rehabilitation of the system is very costly because of the country's rough topography and its widely dispersed population. On the other hand, its small economy places severe constraints on the resources that can be made available to provide the population with an efficient, high quality transport system and services. 1.4 There is no railway at present. However, subregional cooperation studies sponsored by the ADB, as well as Chinese, Malaysian and Thai interests, have examined the eventual linking of the Chinese, Vietnamese and Thai railway systems through Lao In real termns.  - 2 - PDR. Also, survey and design studies have already been carried out for a possible connection of Vientiane to the Thai rail system. 1.5 Road Transport. Road transportation is the major mode of internal communication, estimated to carry more than 90% of freight ton-km and 85% of passenger-km. The country's road network, totals about 14,800 km according to official statistics. However, except for some recent donor financed roads (mainly national), the system has fallen into severe disrepair and normal maintenance is no longer economic on over 50% of the network. Most of the provincial and district road networks consist of tracks which are impassable during the rainy season. 1.6 River Transport. Sections of the Mekong River, comprising about 1,190 km, are navigable, depending on the season and other factors. River transport is mainly complementary to road transport, but for many small communities it remains the only viable means of transport for goods and people. River transport is of the small scale artisanal type because seasonal constraints in depth, difficult channels and lack of navigation aids prevent the efficient use of larger cargo vessels. Loading and unloading is mainly by "gang and plank," since strong currents and extreme seasonal variations in water levels make the construction of river ports uneconomic. Since the improvement of the national road network the share of river transport is said to have shrunk to less than 10%. 1.7 Air Transport. There are two international airports in Vientiane and Luang Prabang as well as about 17 other small airports and airfields distributed throughout the country. A small national airline provides scheduled services and limited international service to the region. In addition, charter services are available on demand. The National Airports Authority (NAA) is an autonomous enterprise under the Prime Minister's Office which is responsible for the four main airports (Vientiane, Luang Prabang, Savannakhet and Pakse) and air traffic services. With donor assistance, rehabilitation and modernization of the entire system (including the air traffic control system) has been started recently. C. Sector Development Strategy 1.8 The Government's transport development strategy focuses on the restoration of vital sections of the transport network, the provision of improved transport services and policy reforms to increase sector efficiency and to facilitate trade and transport. As regards physical targets, the Third Five Year Plan, 1991-1995 (Third Plan), gave first priority to the transport sector (more than 51% of total public investment) and the improvement of the national road network. Road improvement focused on the main Road No. 13 and on providing road access to the southern agricultural areas such as the Bolavens Plateau. In addition, the Government has sought to improve linkages with Thailand and Vietnam, including Road Nos. 8 and 9 as "access to the sea," and to promote transit trade via Lao PDR between China and Thailand. Further priorities were interprovincial roads and the linking of provincial capitals to the national road network.
 - 3 - 1.9 Implementation results of the Third Plan were mixed, mainly because the physical and policy targets were ambitious in the first place, given the very limited implementation capacity of the administration. Apart from the completion of a substantial part of the main arterial Highway No. 13 and the rehabilitation of roads allowing access to the agricultural area of the Bolavens Plateau (Nos. 13B, 16 and 20) all 2 the other Third Plan projects mentioned above have not yet been started. In the policy area the Government has begun to simplify regulations for goods transport, to commercialize and privatize state enterprises, and to encourage private sector participation in transport infrastructure and the provision of services. However, a great deal remains to be done, most important being the adoption of a Road Law and a Traffic Law to simplify and replace the existing array of decrees, regulations and directives. In addition, if Lao PDR is to fully exploit its central geographical position in Indochina as a transit country for its neighbors, a stable legal framework must be created for the cross- border and transit movement of goods, persons and vehicles. This is also one of the targets of policy reforms defined under the Fourth Plan (para. 1. 10, below). 1.10 The Fourth Five Year Plan, 1996-2000 (Fourth Plan), proposes to continue the network development begun under the previous plan and to deepen the agenda of policy and institutional reforms. The targets for the development of physical infrastructure include: * continuation of the reconstruction/rehabilitation of the trunk road system; * creation of international transit corridors to diversify the country's access to the sea and to promote its role as a land bridge for neighboring countries; (reconstruction of inter- and intraprovincial roads to improve access to rural and remote regions); and * establishment of systematic maintenance (routine and periodic) to preserve the new transport infrastructure. Important targets for policy and institutional improvements include: * administrative and process reforms, notably: improving traffic safety; reforming the road classification system; devolving responsibility for certain roads to local authorities; improving the Government's capability to manage local contractors and consultants; strengthening capabilities for the formulation and implementation of construction and maintenance projects; * acceleration of economic reforms relating to transport -- privatization, financial discipline and accountability; and * regulatory measures, in particular adoption of a Traffic Law and a Road Law and measures to facilitate cross-border movements and vehicle control. However, the Mittaphab Bridge across the Mekong at Vientiane, not included in the Plan, was completed during that period.

Lessons Learned from Previous Bank Involvement 1.11 To date, IDA has funded three transport projects in Lao PDR, all in the highway subsector: (i) the Southern Transport Project, which was closed on December 31, 1994 (Credit 1846-LA); (ii) the ongoing Highway Improvement Project (Credit 2218- LA); and (iii) the ongoing Second Highway Improvement Project (Credit 2606-LA), supporting the improvement of about 550 km of Highway No. 13. An Implementation Completion Report (ICR No.1461), dated June 19, 1995, was prepared for the Southern Transport Project. The main lessons learned from that first operation in the road sector were that: (i) in view of the complexity of government and IDA procedures involved with International Competitive Bidding (ICB) procurement, more technical assistance should have been considered to supplement the Borrower's weak implementation capacity; and (ii) future operations require careful planning in view of the limited absorptive and implementation capacity of the Borrower. It should be noted that the physical targets of the Second Highway Project had to be revised because a part of the project funds was reallocated to Credit 2218-LA, owing to cost overruns and changes in project design and scope. The projects have assisted and continue to assist in the creation of a local contracting capacity for road construction and maintenance and, with the support of technical assistance, are contributing to capacity building in transport planning and road maintenance programming. Although this technical assistance has contributed to the training and transferring of skills to Lao counterparts, the implementation capacity of MCTPC still needs to be improved and therefore requires further assistance as well as close supervision by IDA staff. 1.12 IDA's overall portfolio performance in Lao PDR has shown that careful attention must be paid to project design and to realistic project cost estimates, as well as to obtaining adequate and timely budget allocations for counterpart funds for recurrent expenditures. In addition, the experience gained to date suggests that the success of projects depends mainly on: keeping the projects small, simple and focused; establishing only a few key objectives; confining interventions to a relatively small geographic area; building-in adequate technical assistance and training to augment local capacity; and ensuring adequate consultation of stakeholders and full ownership by the client. Furthermore, owing to the constraints discussed above, results will take much longer than normally expected. These considerations have been taken into account in the design and implementation schedule of the proposed project.
 - 5 - THE HIGHWAY SUBSECTOR A. The Road Network and Traffic 2.1 Network. The official network comprises about 14,800 km and is classified into: about 4,100 km of national roads; 5,800 km of provincial roads; and 4,900 km of district roads, which largely consist of rural access roads. However, these statistics need to be put in perspective. Ideally, the national roads should form the primary network, to be used by the bulk of interprovincial and international traffic; provincial roads should provide the main links with the national network and within each province; and district roads should facilitate local transport and natural resource development. However, owing to past hostilities and neglect, only a fraction of the system provides all-purpose use, another fraction can be used only in the dry season or by means of special purpose vehicles and the remainder has become dysfunctional for normal traffic purposes. This means that in practice large parts of the country are cut off from regular commercial and social interaction. It has been estimated that the full restoration of the entire system would cost about US$1.3 billion, which is equivalent to 70% of the country's 1995 GDP (at market prices). 2.2 Of the national roads, approximately 1,000 km have been rebuilt or rehabilitated since 1990 to all-weather standard and another 1,000 km will be rehabilitated by the end of the century. The remainder is in poor condition or can only be used by special purpose vehicles during the dry season. 2.3 Road No. 13. The spine of the road system is National Road No. 13 (1,260 km), linking Pak Mong in the north, about 150 km from the Chinese border, with Kong in the south, close to the Cambodian border, and passing through the major urbanized areas of Luang Prabang, Vientiane, Paksane, Thakhek, Savannakhet and Pakse. It is by far the most important export-import road link in the country. This road facilitates the transportation of agricultural products to deficit (northern) areas and provides access to natural resources, health services, education, employment and other amenities. The Government's plan, supported by IDA and other donors, is to restore this important highway to an all-weather standard by the end of the decade. 2.4 While the ongoing rehabilitation/reconstruction of the national roads will permit national and international access to the country's most important centers of economic activity and to provincial capitals, the situation regarding provincial and district roads will remain critical for some time to come, since there are not enough resources, in terms of funding and implementation capacity, with which to tackle the reconstruction of the entire road network in the short, or even the medium, term. Thus, only about 60% of the country's district centers have all-year access to their provincial centers and 15% have no access even in the dry season.
 2.5 Traffic. The official statistics about the vehicle fleet and traffic are not accurate because of some weaknesses in the collection and processing of the data, the isolation of certain regions, and (possible) underreporting. Studies for highway projects have shown that traffic on rehabilitated roads increased very swiftly, by 15% to 25% per year during the first few years, from a low base of about 50-100 vehicles per day. For example, since the rehabilitation and upgrading of the 270 km Namkading-Savannakhet section of Highway 13, the traffic level on this road stretch has increased by 25% per annum and varies from 170 to 250 vehicles per day depending on the location (1996 survey), which is still very low by regional comparison. Heavy and medium vehicles constituted 30% of this daily traffic, buses 4%, cars 41% and others 25%. Most of the traffic (about 60%) is international and is concentrated around Vientiane Prefecture and the southern/central part of the country. 2.6 Vehicles. Estimates and the accuracy of the data related to the stock of vehicles in the country and its growth rate vary substantially. Depending on the source, the stock of four-wheel vehicles in 1996 was estimated at about 32,000 comprising about one-fifth of medium and heavy vehicles. Heavy vehicle stocks are believed to grow between 3% and 12% per year and light vehicles are believed to grow between 7% and 13% per year. Since the liberalization of international trade, new purchases of vehicles are mainly from Japan and other southeast Asian countries. Up to recent years, vehicle utilization was low, ranging from about 15,000 km per vehicle per year for state transport enterprises to about 30,000 km per vehicle per year for private operators. Load factors were between 40% and 50% with an average load of 3.1 tons and an average load capacity of 7 tons, which indicates that the vehicles were not only relatively small but were also not well utilized. However, since the privatization of all except one state owned transport enterprise, better utilization of the fleet is being witnessed. B. Institutional Environment 2.7 Organization. The organization of the transport sector reflects the broader government organization into three administrative levels: national, provincial and district. Thus, there is a Ministry of Communication, Transport, Post and Construction (MCTPC) at the central level and Divisions of Communication, Transport, Post and Construction (DCTPCs) at the provincial level. District administrations are responsible for local roads. 2.8 At the central level the MCTPC (Chart1) is evolving from an over- centralized, top-heavy organization to a less centralized one. In a reorganization carried out in 19933 the Government attempted to strengthen the MCTPC by separating the policy functions from operations; giving more prominence to the planning and budgeting fumctions; reducing the number of Vice Ministers from five to two and increasing the day-to-day operating responsibilities of the departmental layer of the organization. There are now four line departments reporting through the Vice Ministers to the Minister: 3 Prime Minister's Decree No. 07/PM of January 1993 and subsequent decrees by the Minister of MCTPC (No. 1238/CTPC, No. 1240/CTPC and No. 2328/CTPC).
 - 7 - Communication, responsible for road and waterways management; Transport, Post and Telecommunications; Construction; and Building and Urban Planning. Three other departments, the Minister's Cabinet, the Personnel Department and the Department of Finance provide overall support. The latter includes sections responsible for: Statistics; Budgeting and Planning; International Relations; Accounting and Finance; Management and Privatization; and Audits, as well as a Transport Planning Unit. The Cabinet's Planning and Budgeting Section has branches in the various line departments. 2.9 At the provincial level the central organization is replicated in the 16 provinces by provincial DCTPCs, comprising five sub-divisions: Communication; Transport and Post; Construction; Urban Planning; and Administration and Personnel. However, the provincial DCTPCs lack adequate funding and qualified staff. At the district level road management organizations are not yet fully established and rely mainly on DCTPCs. 2.10 Planning, Budgeting, Control. The Ministry prepares two types of documents: a five-year development plan for infrastructure projects and maintenance as part of the Public Investment Plan process; and yearly budget proposals for the annual appropriations process. The Minister's General Office is responsible for the establishment of planning procedures at the central (MCTPC) and the Department of Finance is responsible for the preparation of the MCTPC budget to be submitted to the Government's budget authorities (e.g., Ministry of Finance, State Planning Committee, Committee for Investment and Cooperation). Regarding infrastructure, a "bottom up" approach is followed. At the central level, the Planning and Budget Divisions of the departments concerned collect the relevant information and the DCPTCs, in cooperation with the Governors' offices, provide input for infrastructure development in the provinces. 2.11 Because the "bottom up" approach has resulted in a large demand for infrastructure, far exceeding available resources, prioritization is critical. However, some projects and programs have been initially funded in the expectation that, once started, they will continue to receive funding. The result has been that human and funding resources have often been spread too thinly, local funding is inadequate and scheduled works are not carried out in accordance with established standards of quality, costs and time. Consequently, GOL has recently introduced new planning and budgeting procedures. While these procedures are too new to be fully evaluated, they are designed to introduce a more coherent and consistent set of criteria to more realistically plan capital expenditures and maintenance expenditures. Procedures and systems need to be developed and clear accountability at all levels for their implementation established. 2.12 Proposals by MCTPC to strengthen planning and budget preparation procedures and to improve accountability at the central and provincial levels have not yet been fully implemented. They are now included in the 1996-2000 Public Investment Plan as part of the agenda for policy and institutional reform.
 - 8 - 2.13 Road Management. Within the MCTPC, the management and delivery of the main road infrastructure rests with the Communication Department. Reporting to the Director of the Department are four line divisions: the Planning and Technical Division; Waterways; Road Construction; and the Road Administration Division (RAD), which handles maintenance with its three regional offices. The Department is responsible for administration, budgeting, and planning, and for the supervision of the improvement and maintenance of national and provincial roads carried out by the DCTPCs. The RAD with its regional offices monitors maintenance programs for national and provincial roads and assists the provinces with the implementation of road improvement and maintenance programs (Char12). 2.14 To date, very little programmed periodic maintenance of roads has been undertaken due, in part, to the absence of a maintainable network. The bulk of maintenance activities has consisted of ad hoc spot improvements and emergency repairs, carried out mainly by sate-owned enterprises (SOEs) and also, in recent years, by private enterprises. From now on, GOL intend to place more emphasis on systematic maintenance of a core maintainable network which has been recently identified and which comprises 6,324 km of national and important provincial roads. In addition, the Ministry intends to progressively undertake the majority of routine maintenance by negotiated/tendered contracts, and all of periodic maintenance by contracts awarded on the basis of competitive bidding. This will require further development of technical, contracting and management skills through training, technical assistance and on-the-job transfer of skills, and will require the development of standard bidding documents for small works adapted to local conditions (para. 3.12). The Government is determined to expedite the transformation of the contracting industry to a more competitive system. However, given the resource and implementation capacity constraints, this transformation is likely to be a gradual process. 2.15 Management of IDA-financed Projects. A Project Coordination Unit (PCU) in the Communication Department was established under the ongoing Highway Improvement Project to oversee the activities relating to IDA-financed highway projects, including the monitoring of all contracts and disbursements. This unit has facilitated communication within the country, with the other donors and with IDA. Currently, the PCU is staffed with a Laotian engineer acting as the project coordinator, assisted by an expatriate project engineer, a secretary and an accountant. The recent assignment of the Laotian project coordinator is a step in the right direction and, as the coordinator gains more experience and training, it is expected that the project management functions will be fully internalized within the Department of Communication. 2.16 Road Design. Most of the road design work to date has been carried out by the two MCTPC SOEs: the Communication Design and Research Institute (CDRI) and the State Enterprise for Survey and Construction Material Laboratory (SESCML). CDRI dominates the market, since it is better eqaipped. There are few other domestic consulting firms in the country involved in the planning, appraisal, design and supervision of road projects. To be competitive, SESCML needs to be strengthened
 - 9 - through the training of its staff, the upgrading of its current stock of equipment and the purchase of additional equipment (para. 3.18). 2.17 Contracting Industry. The contracting industry consists largely of SOEs which, up to recent years, were awarded contracts without competition using centrally fixed unit prices. The prices were not regularly adjusted, and with time, the majority fell below real costs. In addition, the flow of funds was irregular and contract payments were slow. The system resulted in under-capitalized enterprises with old and poorly maintained equipment and inadequate management, financial and administrative skills. Recognizing the ineffectiveness of the system, the Government opted for a policy of competitive bidding and of commercialization, which conferred a limited amount of autonomy on the enterprises. During FY1993/94, all provincial SOEs were commercialized. Currently, 11 SOEs (two nationals and nine provincials) operate in the road construction and maintenance industry. MOF intends to commercialize 8 of them by 1998. In the private sector, about 30 enterprises have the capacity to work in the road sector. It has been estimated the current absorptive capacity of all these enterprises to be about US$19 million per annum in total. 2.18 Under previous IDA-financed projects, equipment and funds were provided to set up "technical contract units" having a status similar to SOEs. Three of these units were converted into one SOE - the Savannakhet Road and Bridge Construction Company (SRBCC)- as part of the ongoing Second Highway Improvement Project. The project provided two direct contracts totaling about US$5.5 million plus technical assistance to help the enterprise develop into a viable candidate for privatization. Despite expressions of interest by some local and foreign entities, no such transaction has as yet taken place. The main reason seemed to be disagreement about the company's valuation. However, the proposed financing arrangement would not qualify the company as privatized in accordance with the modalities agreed under the Third Structural Adjustment Credit (para. 3.38). C. Expenditure and Financing 2.19 Expenditure. As mentioned previously (para. 1.8), the improvement of transport infrastructure has been the Government's overriding priority. Thus, the 1991/95 Third Five-Year Public Investment Plan allocated 51% of a total expenditure of 536 billion Kip to the transport sector, which was equivalent to about 5.5% of the country's GDP during that period. Road improvement and reconstruction represents more than 95% of transport sector investment. (Iakble2., below). 2.20 Almost all the Public Investment Plan expenditure was spent on reconstruction/rehabilitation (notably of Road No. 13) and even the maintenance expenditure was by nature capital expenditure, as the bulk of funds was spent on "spot improvement," which includes anything from landslides to substantial road repair. Systematic road maintenance (i.e., scheduled routine and periodic maintenance) is only now being introduced (in the form of a pilot project). Although the emphasis on network reconstruction/rehabilitation is justified at present and will also play an important role in the future, it is necessary to establish a viable system for regular maintenance (which

There are three major funding sources for capital and recurrent costs: official external assistance from bilateral and multilateral donors (ODA); local funding and private finance. ODA has been by far the most important source of funds. Donors have contributed (1991/95) about 80% of capital expenditure and about 50% of the funds spent on spot improvements. It is likely that the share of local funds will have to increase in the future, since (i) donors are increasingly redirecting their assistance toward other sectors (e.g., education, agriculture, rural areas), and (ii) loan repayments will take an increasing share of the available local funds. 2.22 User Charges. Road user charges (RUCs) are defined as that tax increment which road users pay above the general tax rate. RUCs are a part of taxes and fees on road use in Lao PDR and can be separated into two components, charges on vehicle ownership and charges on vehicle use. Many of the taxes such as import duties, turnover taxes, and excises/contribution taxes also apply to non-transport items and commodities. In addition, there are a set of license, inspection, and registration fees on motor vehicles which parallel those fees on air and water craft. If all RUCs were fully collected at the prevailing rates, about $13 million could be raised from the 1995/96 motor vehicle fleet. However, due to the increasing share of vehicles and fuel which escaped tax and the lower than expected yield on road user fees, the level of 1995/96 RUCs revenues is in the order of $8 million (Annex 2.1). This level of taxes and fees on vehicle use covers the maintenance costs of the core network in FY96/97. However, the maintenance needs are estimated to increase to a stable level of about $15 million beginning in FY2000/2001 (Annex32). Given the substantial investments in transport infrastructure and the high economic (and financial) cost of its neglect, it is critical that

Consequently domestic taxes will have to be raised to compensate. Choice of Improvement Option 4.1 Four options were considered for the road improvement component of the project: (i) routine and minimal periodic maintenance for the existing (gravel) road including spot graveling and grading; (ii) routine and optimal periodic maintenance including spot graveling and grading for the existing (gravel) road; (iii) paved road (Double Bituminous Surface Treatment, DBST) plus routine and periodic maintenance when required; (iv) paved road (asphalt concrete) plus routine and periodic maintenance when required. It was found that the highest NPV and the highest incremental benefit/cost ratio would be obtained with option (iii) (Annex 4.1, Table 3). Consequently, the road improvement component has been based on that option. As far as the periodic maintenance component of the project is concerned, about 600 km of priority roads will be selected on the basis of a multiple criteria comprising mandatory economic evaluation, geographical distribution, traffic volume, network connectivity and year-round accessibility. B. Benefits 4.2 The road improvement component included in the project will contribute to: facilitating export/import and transit traffic; reducing total operating costs (of vehicles and road); providing all-weather, year-round access to the important agricultural areas in the southern part of the country; and linking the provincial capitals in that region to Vientiane. Lower transport costs would also lead to better integration of the south with the north. There would be additional (non-quantifiable) benefits from improved traffic safety, institutional strengthening and training. 4.3 The road maintenance component, covering periodic maintenance on about 600 km of high priority roads, will help preserve past investments in the road infrastructure and reduce the cost of transport for goods and passengers. Equally important, it is expected to be instrumental in introducing systematic road maintenance, developing local maintenance capabilities, strengthening the organization of maintenance at the central and provincial levels and improving their management efficiency. C. Economic Evaluation 4.4 Traffic. It is not appropriate to base traffic forecasts on past and present aggregate trends because, first, the major part of the network is not functional, which means that a substantial part of normal traffic is suppressed, and, second, the existing official traffic statistics are deficient. The National Transport Study team estimated that over the long term normal traffic growth would be between 7% and 10% per year. This is reasonable if compared with past and forecast GDP growth rates. Traffic counts carried out on completed segments of Highway No. 13 have shown growth rates of up to 25% per year. Without doubt, a substantial part of this growth has been generated by the road improvements and it should be borne in mind that the traffic volumes are very low in
 - 31 - absolute terms, even with such high growth rates. Assuming GDP growth between 6% and 8% per year, long-term sustainable growth could well be in the order of magnitude forecast by the NTS. For purposes of economic evaluation, a traffic growth of 7% has been assumed during construction and of 8% per year for normal traffic growth over the life of the road (20 years). Generated traffic is assumed at 25% of the normal traffic in the first year after completion. 4.5 Economic Return and Sensitivity Analysis. The road improvement component includes the cost of construction, construction supervision and physical contingencies for a total of US$39.4 million. Works are assumed to be completed over a three-year period, starting at the end of 1997. After completion, the road will receive routine (every year) and periodic maintenance (every seventh year) totaling US$9.4 million over the lifetime of the road. It has also been assumed that without the investment the road would receive routine maintenance and minimal periodic maintenance. This means that the road would not deteriorate to the status of a bad gravel road. The economic evaluation has been carried out by means of the HDM-III model, by adapting its parameters to values appropriate to conditions in Lao PDR.4 On this basis, the Net Present Value (NPV) for the entire road improvement of 200 km, discounted at 10%, amounts to US$19.45 million and the Economic Rate of Return (ERR) is 19.2% percent (Annex 4.1, Table 1). Various scenarios were developed to test the likely effects of variations in traffic, costs and benefits. The results show that the proposed road improvement is justified, even under adverse assumptions. Only in the unlikely event of a combination of adverse conditions (capital and recurrent increase by 40% and benefits decrease by 40%) would the NPV and ERR become marginal--i.e., below 10% (Annex.4.1. Table 2). 4.6 As regards the pilot periodic maintenance component, the final choice of road segments to form part of the program and comprising about 600 km would attempt to include only sections with a positive NPV (at a 10% discount rate) and an ERR greater than 10%. The road segments tentatively chosen for the program comprise national and provincial roads, paved and unpaved, with traffic volumes estimated between 80 and 150 ADT and with their condition ranging between IRI 6 and 10 on average for paved roads and between IRI 8 and 15 for gravel roads. doc.abstracts: The overall development objective of the Third Highway Improvement Project is to support Lao PDR's economic growth and transition to a market economy. The immediate project objectives are to: a) reduce transport costs; b) improve institutional capacity and effectiveness in managing construction and maintenance activities at the central and provincial levels; and c) introduce routine and periodic road maintenance. The project includes the following components over a five year period: a) road improvements, including road upgrading, construction and consultant services for the supervision of works; b) road maintenance; and c) capacity building including technical assistance, training, consultant services, technical equipment, vehicles, office supplies and incremental costs.
